dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, and fry hats, too.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: We did a little freelance.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (into phone) Let me cali you right back. Frank hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: 21 hosts, 57 ‘forgs.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: But where did you...?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: We found a nest.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Little bastards on the run, guess they find comfort in sticking together.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That’s so stupid -- for them. But it’s brilliant for us. (beat; excited) We should make you guys a task force. You go out, take down these nests.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: And how do we get paid?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Lump sums. Big jackpots. Very classy.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: No thanks, I’1l stick to my assignment. Frank turns to Jake, clinging to this new concept.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: How about it? I’1l put you with Ray -- he’d be great at mass extractions. Jake looks at Remy. Can’t betray his friend.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I don’t run on spec. Give me a pink sheet. Frank lets out a heavy sigh and hands Jake a pink sheet with a yellow receipt attached. Jake scans his assignment

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (impressed) Jarvik job. Out in The Heights.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Nice ‘burb. Who’s the host?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Says J.T. Bonasera.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: James Todd? Is that Jimmy T-Bone?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The record producer. Half a year past due.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: But the guy’s gotta be a billionaire.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Tax evasion -- IRS tagged his residuals. Every time you hear one of his tunes, the feds get a little richer.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: How come I never heard of this guy?  19.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: ‘Cause you gotta have taste.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I have taste.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. He’s the one that did Baby in My Sleeve. Carol and me, that was our song.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: So it’s a mercy killing.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: That's real nice.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Listen, I/11 make you a deal. You come watch the game at my place tomorrow, and I’11l switch you this guy for Jamie Mulhearn. Remy hesitates, masking his relief.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. T-Bone deserves to get his heart ripped out by someone who appreciates his work. As they exchange pink slips... INT. REMY AND CAROL’S HOUSE - NIGHT Remy enters to find Carol sitting on the couch, beneath a shelf filled with trinkets from her store.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Hey. I got your wings.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Already ate.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Mind if I have ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Would that be before or after you help Peter with his homework? Remy checks his watch. Winces. Knows he screwed up. Remy drops the sack of food on the coffee table. Surprise Carol when he cuddles up next to her on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (quietly) Hey, remember that song Baby in My Sleeve? Jimmy T-Bone --

dialogues.speaker: SUDDEN FLASHBACK --
dialogues.text: THE SAME HOUSE -- moving boxes litter the floor. A BABY, maybe two months old, sleeps in a carrier atop the same coffee table. MOVING PAST... Remy stands on the brand new couch, hanging the shelf on the wall above it. A younger, sexier Carol, wearing a nurse’s uniform, dance over to him, hips swaying to the smooth hip-hop-jazz riff of Jimmy T-Bone’s Baby in My Sleeve. She climbs up on the couch, comes up behind Remy -- Kisses his ear, takes the hammer from his hand and drops to the floor. Remy turns into her, unzipping her uniform Lowering her to the couch, the two falling into one anoth

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Where the now older, world-weary Carol moves away from Remy.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah, I remember. What about it?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Forget it. Remy’s up and out of there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy carefully cracks the bedroom door, then sneaks into. INT. PETER’S ROOM - NIGHT Remy crosses the darkened room, stands over a sleeping PETER, his 10-year-old son. Runs a finger across his chee Quietly:

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Sorry, buddy. Remy turns to leave the room. Peter calls out to him, groggy.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Did you do your report?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I started.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I’1l help you finish in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Okay. It’s on the Romans.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: They were some bad-ass dudes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Did you know they used to make people fight with lions?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Barbaric. Go to sleep. Remy heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Dad, why did the Romans stone people to death?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Because they didn’t have any guns. Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Night. And Remy closes the door behind him... INT. REMY AND CAROL’S HOUSE - MORNING Remy sits over a bowl of cereal. Carol, across from him, reads the paper. It’s silent. Peter carries in several books.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You ready, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Maybe we can skip the homework until later tonight. First let’s go watch the game at Uncle Jake's.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Peter, Jake is not your uncle.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: And tell your father we didn’t discuss anything about going to his house.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Tell your mother it’s just a barbeque

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I thought you had to work.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: It’s a night job. Come on, it’1ll be good for the kid to get out. . OFF Carol, unhappy but resigned... EXT. JAKE’S HOUSE - BACKYARD - DAY Remy navigates his way through the crowded backyard, dragging Carol and Peter behind him. Peter’s face is buri in a handheld video game. Jake spots them coming.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hey, brought the whole family. (rubs Peter's head) You want a hot dog, Ham-bone?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I guess so. Jake throws a hot dog on the grill. Peter fixes his hair.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You have a good day at school?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It’s Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: So? When I was your age, we went to school every day. And at night, too.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Nuh-uh.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Don’t lie to my child, Jake. Jake rolls his eyes to Remy. Remy shrugs. His cell phone RINGS. He pops it open.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Yeah? (beat) No, I’m not home. It’s not a good time. (beat) Christ. Fine, take it to 1450 Greendale. Two minutes. Remy snaps the phone closed.  23.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: What? Nothing. I left some equipment at the office. Remy walks quickly to Jake, talks quietly. REMY (CONT’D) Gimme your apron.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I got a mobile coming in. Keep Carol and Peter busy. He takes Jake’s apron and heads out. Jake calls over towa Peter...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hey, Peter, you wanna flip some burgers?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Can we make the fire higher?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: c’mere, you little pyro. Remy veers over towards Carol.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I’1l be right back. EXT. JAKE’S HOUSE - FRONT YARD - DAY Remy waits at the curb, Jake’s red and white checkered apron tied around his waist. A taxi cab pulls into the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CAB
dialogues.text: The FARE peers nervously out the window from the backseat

dialogues.speaker: FARE
dialogues.text: I just want the Fairfield Downtown --

dialogues.speaker: CABBIE
dialogues.text: Quick errand, buddy. Don’t worry, I ain't charging. The Cabbie makes a show of turning off the meter. On the passenger seat is an artiforg scanner, blinking PAST DUE. Remy approaches the cab.

dialogues.speaker: FARE
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: CABBIE
dialogues.text: Relax, fella. Guy’s a friend of mine. The fare, spooked, reaches for the far door handle -- but it’s broken off. No way out. He turns back -- Remy opens the. cab door and TASERS the guy. He slumps.

dialogues.speaker: THE CABBIE
dialogues.text: Adjusts the rear view mirror as Remy goes to work.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE REAR VIEW
dialogues.text: Scalpels fly, blood splatters. Remy moves quickly. After a few moments, a bloodied Remy appears at the Cabbie’s window; Remy tosses two hundred bucks at the guy

dialogues.speaker: CABBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For an extra fin, I'll get rid of the body. Remy tosses him a twenty. He hears a commotion behind him

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Carol, wait -- I’ve got a blanket --

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s fine, my sweater’s in the car -- Remy jerks around to see Carol coming out of the house, Peter at her side. Jake follows behind, trying to get her to come back inside -- No luck. Carol stops on the front step -- freezes -- There’s Remy, bloodied, holding an artiforg as the cab drives away. He, too, is frozen. Peter actually looks up at his father for once -- Then, unimpressed, goes back to his video game. CAROL (CONT’D) I am so done with this.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Cc’mon, it’s just a kidney... Carol drags Peter into their car and guns the engine. As she drives away.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I couldn’t keep her busy.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I saw that. Jake throws his arm around Remy.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I’‘1l give you a ride home after the game. INT. JAKE’S CAR - NIGHT Jake pulls up into Remy’s driveway. Remy sighs as he eyes the house. Lingering in the car.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I don’t know how you put up with it.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Every man’s suburban dream.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Not mine.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna go do the T-Bone job first. Give her time to calm down. You gonna head over to Jamie Mulhearn’s?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Already been there. He says to say hi.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You didn’t do it?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Oh, I did the job. He said to say hi before that part. Remy climbs out of the car. Stares at the house with drea Jake backs out. Remy heads straight for his own car and climbs in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIMMY “T-BONE” BONASERA sits behind the mixing board in h home studio, fiddling with various knobs and switches, fi tuning the smooth riff that emanates from the speakers. Remy approaches quietly from behind as T-Bone lifts a via of sparkling red powder, rubbing the substance into his gums .

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Nice house. T-Bone turns off the music, but doesn’t turn around.  26.

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Ain’t really mine anymore. You with the IRS?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: Soul suckers are taking everything E back.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: So am I. T-Bone turns and looks at Remy for the first time. Spots the duffel bag. The defibrillator unit. The tattoo.

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: (nods) Can I finish this song?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Of course. I’m a big fan.

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: You could help. My assistant left two weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I’ve never made music before.

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: It ain’t complicated. A song’s just a whole mess of tiny parts working together. All you gotta do is break the song back down. Extract the individual parts.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I can probably do that. As Remy takes a seat behind the mixing board...

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: LATER. The final strains of the newly mixed song pour out of the speakers. T-Bone listens, rapt, eyes closed. Remy can’t control his smile, overwhelmed by the experience.

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: Now that’s a hit right there.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: The IRS will be thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: Do me a favor. See that Mad Dog over at Blue Note Records gets this.  27.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: It’s done. T-Bone pops out a memory stick; Remy puts it in his duffe

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: So we gonna do this, or what?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I really am a big fan.

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: A gig’s a gig, right? Should I sit, stand?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Easiest if you laid down. T-Bone lies on the floor. He unbuttons his shirt, then pours a little more red powder and rubs it into his gums one last time. His hand shakes a bit as he offers the via to Remy.

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: Wanna Q up?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I should probably do this straight. He hands T-Bone a pen and a yellow repo receipt. REMY (CONT’D) Do you mind? Less paperwork if I can get the client to sign off before... T-Bone signs his name on the bottom of the receipt, and Remy nods his thanks. He lines up a scalpel, electric saw and a suction unit, then gathers the defibrillator.

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: What’s that thing for?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: It’s a defib unit. Jarvik stops pumping when you jolt it with an electric pulse. Keeps me from losing a finger. Remy flips the defib unit on and it HUMS to life. He twists the dial to 300...

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: This gonna hurt? Remy rubs the shock pads together.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You won’t feel a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T-Bone closes his eyes. Remy places the shock pads on T- Bone’s chest. Depresses the thumb buttons, and suddenly..

dialogues.speaker: SPARKS
dialogues.text: erupt out of the defibrillator pads! The explosion sends Remy FLYING BACKWARDS through the air -- body twisted -- FREEZE-FRAME on half-dead Remy, mid-flight.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I have been knocked unconscious on three separate occasions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy sits on a long bench, in military dress. Several soldiers wait alongside him.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: First day overseas, my regiment was sent for tests to see how we could best assist the U.S. Military in the African campaign. Muffled BOOMS begin filtering through the walls. At first they’re soft, but they grow louder... boom... Boom... BOO Silence. After a moment, a door opens at the far end of t hall. A NURSE steps out with a clipboard and stares at Remy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big, gleaming white room. Sterile. In the center: Remy, strapped to a metal framework that conforms to his body like a vertical beach chair. A DOCTOR pulls hard on each strap, then slips a pair of goggles with wires coming out of them over Remy’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: What is this thing?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: It’s a control chair. For the concussion test. Head back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor squishes a helmet over Remy’s head.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: The what test? But the doctor’s disappeared. Remy turns back, and sudden  29.

dialogues.speaker: THE SAHARA DESERT
dialogues.text: appears all around him. Nothing but sand for miles. A muffled BOOM sounds in the distance, with a flash of ligh Remy squints, trying to make out the source of the explosion. REMY (CONT’D) Hello? Am I supposed to do something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through a one-way mirror, we can SEE Remy, the chair shaking him around as the BOOMS grow louder. The doctor takes a sip of tea and grabs a baseball bat, wrapped in plastic, from a rack of bats on the wall. The sign above reads STERILE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bat in hand, the doctor re-enters. Remy is still strapped in his chair, grimacing as the virtual explosions intensify. REMY‘S POV - AN ARC OF FIRE coming closer -- a missile heading directly for him, and

dialogues.speaker: THE DOCTOR
dialogues.text: WHACKS Remy in the head with the baseball bat. curt TO: BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That was knockout number one. Moaning. Not erotic one bit. It’s the sound of pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy’s eyes flutter open, and he staggers to his feet -- Inside a long recovery room, filled with cots and moaning soldiers, most still out cold. Remy’s the only one standing. The doctor approaches.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Congratulations, son. You’ve got a very small brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy sits in a control chair -- like the one in the concussion test -- at the front of this high-tech tank.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Small brains, big skulls. That’s why Jake and I came out of concussions as fast as we did. Jake sits behind him in the gunner’s chair. A thin panel glass is between them. Remy puts his thumb on one side of the glass, Jake does it on the other --

dialogues.speaker: PRESSING THUMBS TOGETHER
dialogues.text: as a light zaps across the surface, and the TANK ENGINE roars to life. We have ignition.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And that’s why they put us in a tank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A row of tanks maneuver deftly over the sand, side-by-sid

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But by the time we finished training, the war was already winding down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy writes a postcard; Jake plays solitaire. The monitor in their tank shows three enemy soldiers waving frantically, trying to surrender.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It gave me time to write to Beth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tanks mindlessly ROLL OVER the three soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy’s writing yet another letter in back as Jake steers the tank, gleefully targeting rabbits and snakes.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But the more often I wrote, the less I heard back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tanks roll to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then, one night, it was over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freezing soldiers sitting side-by-side as they make their way back to America. Remy flips through a meager pile of letters.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I hadn’t heard from Beth in two months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy strolls purposefully through the red-light area.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My plan was to go in there, sweep her off her feet, and take her away from all this mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy storms in, past the waiting clients. The familiar MOANS emanate from behind the curtain. Remy storms throug INT. BETH’S ROOM - BROTHEL - NIGHT Two beefy MARINES are servicing the lady on the bed --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Beth, your husband is home! The marines turn -- the girl on the bed sits up -- It’s not Beth. The new prostitute SCREAMS -- The Marines, scowls on their faces, leap out of bed, draw back their fists -- the punches FLY forward --

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And that takes care of the second time I was knocked unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy’s frozen in mid-air, having been shocked by the electric defibrillator paddles. Somewhere, a typewriter

dialogues.speaker: CLACKS --
dialogues.text: UNFREEZE. The mid-air fall resumes, Remy blasted backward SLAMMING into a wall, crumpling to the floor below.  32. His eyes are open, but glazing over. A trickle of blood runs from his nose. His palms are burned and blackened.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Blackout number three. This time, I was legally dead for twenty minutes. Jimmy T-Bone sits up and sees Remy laid out on the carpet

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If T-Bone hadn’t spooked and called the meds, there’d be no more story to tell. The guy grabs for a phone and frantically starts dialing.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Everybody's gotta be a fucking hero. We HOLD on Remy’s blank stare as everything slowly goes.. BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When I came to, the first thing I saw was... CLEAVAGE. A GREAT SET.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I think he’s awake. INT. REMY’S HOSPITAL ROOM - DAY Remy’s nurse pulls back. Hospital ceiling above. Jake and Frank pop into frame, staring down at us --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Gave us a scare there, pal.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Looking good. Looking real good. Remy’s about as far from good as you can get. An IV drips into his wrist; a machine displays his weak blood pressur

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (barely above a whisper) The... client...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Lookit this guy -- two seconds out of a coma and he’s worried about work.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I got him, buddy. Soon as the medics cleared you, I finished the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy weakly holds out his thumb; Jake presses his against it. Remy looks around the empty room --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Carol...?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I called her. She knows. I don’t think she’s sending flowers any time soon. Remy nods. Then...

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I can’t... remember -- what --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Faulty shock unit. We got the boys in the shop looking at it right now. Jake and Frank share a look -- Remy notices --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: What? What is it? Frank nudges Jake; wants him to do the talking.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You know I woulda come either way. For you, no question -- but we do have some business to discuss.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Sure. Yeah. Take my jobs for a few days... ‘till I get back --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: It’s not... It’s not that. Remy’s confused. Jake looks ashamed. Remy follows his gaz over to

dialogues.speaker: A SMALL METALLIC BOX
dialogues.text: on a tall wheeled cart. Silicon tubing snakes out and int an open incision in Remy’s chest.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s a Jarvik 39. Top of the line --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: No. No no no -- get it out --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Ten million beat warranty, it’s got the no-rust valves, the undercoating - Remy starts to pull at the tubes; Jake grabs his hands --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You got hit hard, man. It’s all scar tissue in there --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I feel fine -- lemme go --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The unit’s already doing the work. ‘All you have to do is sign a few papers and they can put it in and sew you up, better than new. The warranty alone --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Don’t you sell me. Don’t you -- I am not a fucking client --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Course you’ re not. You’re the top Repo Man in this whole damn town. And you can still gas, grab, and go, but you gotta have a ticker to play the game. Remy looks to Jake, who can barely meet his gaze, then to Frank. Maybe he’s right...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You owe it to your family. You owe it to yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy staggers down the hallway, yanking out tubes and wir as he goes, the Jarvik-39 skittering behind on its tall cart. Jake and Frank jog after Remy --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What? What’d I say?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You asshole. A nurse scowls at Remy as he stumbles by.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Sir, that’s hospital property -- Remy reaches into his own bloody chest incision -- wincin with the pain -- and unhooks the main tube. The Jarvik ca slows to a halt as Remy lurches for the exit doors.

dialogues.text: cnagene  36. INT. REMY AND CAROL’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Remy, on shaky legs, shuffles into the darkened house.

dialogues.text: So you're not going to die?

dialogues.text: Jake drinking, laughing. The usual. Remy sits beside him, trying to muster up his best fake smile.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Suddenly, everything was different.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: And then the guy just started crying. Bawling like a little girl, begging. And this snot bubble comes out of his nose, and the harder he cried, the bigger it got. Bigger and smaller, bigger and smaller... PUSH IN on Remy...

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was still swapping stories with Jake about some shmuck and his overdue liver, but now all I could think about was how the host had a name. And a wife. Kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy sits in his car, alone. The parking lot is empty.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And how he didn’t deserve to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy turns out the light and climbs onto the couch to go sleep. Carol wanders in, several envelopes in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I think there was a mistake on your commission check.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: There’s no mistake. Things are slow.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Don’t piss away your last shred of usefulness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy stares her down -- then pulls the blanket over his head so he doesn’t have to look at her. INT. FRANK’S OFFICE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I did my job. It was all I knew. Frank grinds through his paperwork. Remy enters.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Just the man I wanted to see. Frank tosses Remy a pink assignment sheet. FRANK (CONT’D) I know you're taking a hit on that payment plan, so I saved this one for you. Big commission -- fifteen different ‘forgs.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Addict?

dialogues.text: Probably. And get this -- two overdue. Snitch tracked her to the metal graveyard south of Broxton. Remy nods, tucks the sheet under his arm, and heads out. FRANK (CONT’D) (calling out) Faster the better. Twenty percent commission if you get it here by tomorrow. INT. REMY’S CAR - NIGHT Remy speeds through the night, windows down.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I didn’t take a long look at the file. Maybe it was the rush job. Maybe deep down I knew.

After several beats of silence, a SCREAM pierces the air. Remy emerges from the house carrying a lacquered box, grinning like a kid who’s gotten laid for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: BioMedical Repossession Division. Level One.

dialogues.text: Why are you doing this for me?

dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.text: It’s fine.

dialogues.text: I just wanted someone to talk to around here.

dialogues.text: Remy’s in full Repo gear, black-on-black.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (quietly) Eventually. Remy backs out of the room without waking him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'd like to say I left to keep Carol from having to take on my financial burdens. INT. PETER’S ROOM - NIGHT Peter stirs awake. Rubs his eyes, looks out the window --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As his dad loads up his car and pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH A WINDOW

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But it was something else that drew me away. Remy reclines his car seat and pulls a jacket over him fo warmth. He’s going to sleep out in the car tonight.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My living situation was one thing. My work situation was another. No repos meant no cash, which meant no payments to the Union, which meant no future.

dialogues.text: So what happens if somebody catches you at the computer?

dialogues.text: Entering falsified returns, grounds for immediate dismissal.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to lose your job.

dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.text: Don’t worry. I’ve got a foolproof plan.

dialogues.text: Don’t get caught.

dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.text: Do you have any idea how much you owe?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea how bad you look? Beth throws a noodle at him; Remy ducks it.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Be nice. I’m your wife.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Ex-wife. And this is as nice as I get. The scanner WHOOPS it up again; yet another readout from Beth’s overdue body.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you even know how many ‘forgs you've got in there?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Let’s see... liver, pancreas, kidneys, stomach, and lungs from the cancer. As upgrades, I’ve got eyes, ears, voice box, tits --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Hey, it’s a tough gig out there. Hooker down the street shows up with glow-in-the-dark vulva, you can bet every girl in the district’s gonna have a new neon hoochie inside a week.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You're shittin’ me. I’ve never even heard of that.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Wanna see? Beth moves towards him.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jackson Reproductive Replacement System, Release five-point-three. She straddles Remy; he barely protests. She unbuttons her shirt, placing Remy’s hand on her bare belly.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s right behind my Kenton stomach ES/18. Lady Mystique model. Comes in six sparkling colors.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Which one did you choose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth moves Remy’s arm further down her body --

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Shocking... pink...

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: And your hips... Remy slides his hands down her hips, moving them across h waist, her legs --

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Flexor Durajoints... million step warranty... Now Remy’s clothes are coming off, too --

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You haven’t asked me about my lips...

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (feeble protest) Come on. I’m married.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Yeah. To me.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I guess I never signed any divorce papers.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Me neither. And then Beth pulls Remy into a hard kiss as they move in one another -- naked now, free -- The artiforg printouts fall to either side as Remy throws Beth down on the table, their bodies thrusting desperately...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy wakes up beside a naked Beth. Tries to sneak out of bed, but she wakes...

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Last time, that cost you a hundred bucks.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: And now? Beth thinks for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Free.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: How ‘bout that.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I’m a shitty business woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy sneaks through piles of lacquered boxes, each one an artiforg that’s been returned to the Union.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A mortgage. Motel rent. A manager who wanted double or he’d snitch. And that damn Jarvik, ticking away inside my chest. He grabs a lacquered box, opens it, and takes out the metallic organ within. He begins rasping away the serial number with a metal file.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It all took cash, and I didn’t have the guts anymore. But I could make it seem like I did.

dialogues.speaker: REMY AT THE COMPUTER
dialogues.text: Typing fast, keying in the serial number from a pink slip Glancing around nervously.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Beth had fifteen outstanding accounts, so I found fifteen replacement parts. I actually got the computer to buy my story. My foolproof plan, put into action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy sneaks by a sleeping GUARD, then turns --

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Except for the part about not getting caught. Jake is there. He’s seen everything.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Hey. They stare at each other; neither knows what to say. Jake leans against the Credit Union sphere-and-bolt statue. Wh it finally begins, their conversation is as casual as eve

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: My uncle was a bank robber. I ever tell you that?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Uncle Joe?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Nah, my mom's brother, Lou. Made a whole mess of the West Coast, knockin’ over savings and loans.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: And the man was good at it -- nobody knew a damn thing. Most days, he woke up and went to work at the auto shop, but every so often he’d skip out for lunch and pull on a ski mask. Fifteen years he did this. And then one day, he forgot to wear gloves, and they pulled a print from some bullshit drunk and disorderly twenty years back. A day later, the cops were knocking on his door.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Lemme guess -- he was relieved.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: No, he was fucking pissed. (beat; softer) But he just wasn’t that guy anymore. He was off his game, and he knew it.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Maybe it was a blessing.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Maybe. They stare at each other, understanding each other perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do for money? I can’t do anything else.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: It’d be the same for me.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Then what?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You find a way. Talk to Frank about the sales thing. Make Carol happy.  56.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: And if I suck at it?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Do something else. But you gotta keep those payments coming. Soon as you fall behind, that’s Day One.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: And six months later...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: We put a guy on you. Remy stares off, the reality hitting him hard. He sees Raymond Pearl walking off with a fresh pink sheet.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Probably Ray.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Or me. Job’s a job.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Job’s a job. Remy turns to leave. His fate is set. Then turns back --

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Uncle Lou.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You know that erotic cake shop up on eighth street? That’s his.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Is he happy?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: He makes pornographic desserts for a living. You tell me. Jake and Remy share one last grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy shuffles away from the mall, only a few parking lot halogens lighting his lonely path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy sits across from a beleaguered looking Frank.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Frank surprised me. He took it better than I expected. Frank erases Remy’s name from the big board. Then -- thro the eraser at the wall in anger. He’s lost his best guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy, looking uncomfortable in suit and tie, sits across from a family of four in a sales booth.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Mr. Timmons, you owe it to your family. You owe it to yourself. The sickly looking patriarch nods and takes the pen. But before he signs, Remy continues... REMY (CONT’D) ‘Course, if you can’t pay your bills, some Union guy like me might show up next to your bed, wake you out of a sound sleep and run a scalpel from your collar bone down to your pelvis to reclaim our property. (beat) I’m just saying. The man drops the pen. His wife faints.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wasn’t cut out for sales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy raises a cleaver high into the air. His apron is covered in blood.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I had to work. So I tried something a little more in line with my training. Remy slams the cleaver down onto a butcher block -- separating a sirloin steak. Remy’s trying his hand behind the deli counter. He whacks at a slab of meat, over and over again, juices flying --

dialogues.speaker: THE DELI CUSTOMERS
dialogues.text: back away from the counter, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Six months, and I must have tried twenty different jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy, in an embarrassing T.G.I.Friday’s type ensemble delivers several meals to a table full of college guys. O particularly assholish frat guy waves Remy over, lifts hi hamburger bun to show that his food is not cooked right.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The customer, they say, is always right. I’d never really thought about what that meant before. Remy takes the basket of food and jams it into the guy’s face, knocking him over in his chair -- And then wailing on him while the stunned frat boys look on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy and Beth pack up. Clothes. Work gear. He gently pack away his scalpels, ether cannisters... Looks at them fond

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s amazing how fast a hundred and eighty days can go by. Beth puts a hand on Remy’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: If you go with me, you’re done.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I’m done anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crappy street. Crappy neighborhood. Remy and Beth, their bags at their feet, stand outside Remy’s car. Remy pulls out a glass bottle filled with gas, a soaked r in the neck. He lights the rag with a match -- And tosses the bottle into the front seat of his car. He and Beth walk away, bags in hand, as the fire engulfs the car, erasing any trace of its existence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy and Beth keep their heads low as they stick to the shadows along a trash-strewn sidewalk. As they head toward the entrance of this sad excuse for a building, we realize it’s the same burned-out hotel on th same ugly abandoned road where we first met Remy.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Welcome to paradise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy and Beth scope out the rooms, trying to find a suitable place to hide out.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There are hiders, and there are seekers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth takes the reins, showing Remy how and where to board up the windows, doors, setting booby traps, etc.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hiding was new to me. But Beth had practice. She reaches over and turns off Remy’s flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Rule number one: Natural light only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Beth and Remy root through a dumpster. Remy holds up t pieces of fabric, one blue, one red. Beth points to the red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they hang the red fabric over the window.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Curtains!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy RIPS open a hole in the wall with a hammer and fluff pink insulation pops out. Beth grabs a handful and shoves it into a pillowcase, and Remy does likewise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The decorations are complete, a woman's touch amid the debris. Candles, a blue tarp for a tablecloth, a stolen mattress for a bed. Flowers poke out of cracks in the wal Remy lays out weapons: Taser, scalpel, shotgun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy searches through piles of broken furniture, testing busted chair legs and posts for use as potential weapons. As he swings a piece of wood through the air, he notices something beneath a pile. He clears away trash to find:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old typewriter. He grabs it, blows off the dust. Tests the weight, as if to use it to crush in someone’s head, b then gets another idea... The faint CLACK of a typewriter sends us:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACING through the dilapidated lobby, up the stairs, and into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Remy sits at the typewriter, naked, back where we m him at the very beginning. We’re now where we first came in.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But you can only hide for so long before they find you. Suddenly, LAUGHTER. Remy, spooked, leaps to his feet. Shotgun in one hand, pistol suddenly in the other. Laughter again. Distinct. High-pitched. Remy tenses --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy, shotgun in hand, follows the laughter. Coming from down the hall --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louder now, interspersed with voices. Remy presses himsel against the wall, breathing hard. Shotgun out the window Children. THREE LITTLE GIRLS, playing in the courtyard below. Remy relaxes as the girls pull out a jump-rope and begin chanting a song to count out their game:

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRLS
dialogues.text: There was a man from Troubadour/ Who got blown up during The War/ He did not die, would not concede/ How many artiforgs did he need? Stomach! Bladder! Pancreas! Eyes! Intestine! Heart! Kidney! Liver... Remy shakes his head at his own paranoia --

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (O0.S.)
dialogues.text: If you're going to shoot the kids, aim for the big one. More meat on her.  61. Remy lowers the shotgun barrel and turns to find Beth. Sh tosses his clothes at him. Remy begins to dress as Beth walks over by the typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For a guy who’s so paranoid, you sure make a lot of noise.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: The writing helps me think.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: What is it? A book? Epic poem?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: It’s a letter.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: To who?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Peter. My son.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I never played you for a dad.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Neither did I. Beth moves forward, then stops -- alarmed --

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Somebody’s coming.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You don’t hear it? Beth and Remy peek out the window, peering down to the street.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: All I hear are those damn kids.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN IN THE COURTYARD
dialogues.text: The girls are still jumping rope, now singing...

dialogues.speaker: JUMP ROPE GIRLS
dialogues.text: Tell it to the Mama/ Tell it to the son/ They all be gone when the day is done/ On come the wrinkles/ On come the sneeze/ The old man dies on his old man knees...

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: Beth grabs Remy’s ear lobe, twisting. He yelps.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Still natural? I can’t believe you haven't upgraded these. Beth digs through a nearby crate and fishes out a long, thin wire. Tiny pad on one end, a metallic jack on the other.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put this in your ear. Remy looks down at the tiny pad, watching as Beth inserts the metallic jack into her ear cavity. It digs in tight, finally CLICKING into place.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Vocom makes share wires?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: It’s aftermarket. Shut up and listen. Remy puts the “earphone” into his ear to share Beth’s amplified hearing. Suddenly, bis world comes alive with sound. Past the girl singing. Past the traffic. Finding a BARKING dog in the distance. An arguing couple, ignoring the quiet CRIES of the baby in the next room.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (incredibly loud) What am I -- Remy and Beth both cringe at his overly amplified voice. Beth scolds him with her eyes, showing him the small whee controls in the skin behind her ear that she continues to amplify, screening out the ambience. Focusing. Wings flapping. Footsteps. And finally, the familiar PING! PING! of an official Union-issue scanner. Remy yanks the wire out of both of their ears. REMY (CONT’D) Get away from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond Pearl reaches into his duffel, extracting a taser a scalpel, and an enormous gun. Clearly not Union issue.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Who is that?  63.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Ray Pearl. Psychopath with a Union scalpel.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (grabs Remy’s gun) I’ve got something for him.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: He’s not here for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gun in hand, Raymond strides right past the jump rope girls. They continue their chant, the rhythm growing faster...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tension mounting as Remy and Beth run short on time.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: There’s the back fire escape --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: No. I have something better. Follow me. As Beth follows Remy towards the hall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond’s boots kick up dust as he mounts the stairs, his scanner honing in. PING - PING - PING -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the jump rope girls’ feet, skipping impossibly fast.

dialogues.speaker: JUMP ROPE GIRLS
dialogues.text: The old man dies on his old man knees!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond kicks a door off its remaining hinge. The room is charred out. A blue tarp sits on the otherwise rotted floor. Remy sits on the far side of the room, typing.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Pathetic. I can’t believe you were a Level Five. Remy looks up. Mock surprise.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: They sent the ear guy after me? That hurts.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: You're a funny guy. I’11 laugh at that when I got your heart in my hand.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (seductively) Ooh. Come here, sweet talker.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: It’s gonna be a pleasure rippin’ off that tattoo. Remy stands for a fight. Raymond bull rushes. And just as he trounces across the middle of the blue tarp...

dialogues.speaker: THE BURNED OUT FLOOR GIVES WAY
dialogues.text: Wood splintering, cracking -- Raymond plunging downward. Remy looks up at Beth, who was hiding behind the door. Th share a smile... UNTIL THE REST OF THE FLOOR CONTINUES TO CRUMBLE. Beth backs up against the wall -- the floor cracking towards her -- Remy leaping -- but she’s swallowed up -- Remy watches in horror as Beth plunges two stories down, loud CRACK as she hits the floor near Raymond. Remy bolts

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth lays amid a ton of debris, barely conscious, clutchi her badly twisted knee. She spots Remy’s gun on the floor nearby. Reaches -- straining -- Raymond drags himself along the floor, battered and bloodied, but still moving forward. He grabs the gun, looks up --

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: You'll do. A sick smile crosses his lips -- he pulls the trigger --

dialogues.speaker: A FOOT
dialogues.text: Stomps Raymond’s hand back down, pinning the gun to the floor. The SHOT goes wild. Raymond looks up to see Remy standing over him, pumping t sawed-off shotgun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A terrifying BLAST freaks out the jump rope girls. As the sprint off, leaving their jump rope behind... .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy carries an unconscious Beth toward their room. She emits a small groan, eyelids fluttering.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (soft, almost tender) Hey, there. You’re back with us. Beth’s hand rifles upward, clamping hard around Remy’s throat. They both fall to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (choking) Beth -- it’s me -- Beth’s eyes flutter open. She realizes it’s Remy and quickly releases him. Remy coughs -- REMY (CONT’D) Jesus Christ --

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Sorry. You live on the streets long enough... She brushes herself off and tries to stand -- Nearly falling again. Her artiforg knee is a mess.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Let me carry you.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I’ve got it. Beth tries to take a few more steps, but limps horribly.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Come on, you’re leaking hydraulic fluid all over. BETH . I can fix it myself. She sits on the floor and tears open her pants, exposing her open wound. Her metallic kneecap glints in the moonlight, the artiforg metal puncturing her natural fles Reaching into her bra, Beth pulls out a small package of tools -- screwdriver, hammer, miniature soldering iron. S fiddles with the artiforg, wincing from the pain.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (staring at her knee) You know how quick I could pluck that Dura-joint right outta your leg?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (grunting through pain) Wouldn't -- really -- help us.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Under 12 seconds. Beth stops what she’s doing and looks at Remy, then twist away at something metal in her leg. It CLICKS.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I think I got it. Help me up. Remy pulls Beth to her feet. Her limp’s not so bad now, b she’s clearly in pain. BETH (CONT’D) It‘ll hold.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: We can’t rest, we have to go. They found me faster than I thought.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You think there’11l be more of them?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Once they’re on you, they don’t stop.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: So what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mall, as usual, is abuzz with activity. Remy slinks down a side street and into an alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry The Lung steps out into the alley and, with a grunt removes the top half of his costume. He’s just a teenager The half-dressed lung pulls out a cigarette and lights up

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Hell of an example you're setting.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY THE LUNG
dialogues.text: ‘Hey, pal, I’m on a break -- Remy steps out, and Larry’s eyes go wide -- LARRY THE LUNG (CONT’D) Sir, I didn’t -- I mean --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I got a thirty-four waist. You?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY THE LUNG
dialogues.text: Th -- Thirty.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Fucking metabolism... A swift ELBOW to Larry’s head, and the kid CRASHES to the ground. Remy stomps out the cigarette still in Larry's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowded, as usual. Customers wait in line outside the Union. Larry The Lung, in full costume, walks toward the Union; customers wave and smile at him, and he waves back. REMY’S POV - INSIDE THE COSTUME there’s little room to maneuver. Remy peers out through t hidden mesh eyeholes, trying to keep up the act. He walks down the line of ailing. customers --

dialogues.speaker: HEAVYSET MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey, Larry! Remy is spun around by a HEAVYSET MAN holding a coughing dog.

dialogues.speaker: HEAVYSET MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think we could get a picture? The guy throws an arm around Remy, lifting the dying pooc into his face as his WIFE takes a snapshot. He sing-songs HEAVYSET MAN (CONT’D) We’re gonna get Muffin here a new widdle biddie heart, aren’t we? Yes we are! Top of the line! Yes we are! Remy extricates himself and heads for the Union doors. As usual, two GUARDS man the metal detectors. Remy does his best to wave at them -- they wave back -- h walks through -- ALARMS BLARE. Remy instinctively keeps walking -- But ARMED GUARDS swarm out of every crevice like roaches with the lights turned off. Customers start to shout -- Remy spins -- more guards -- Turns back to run out -- even more -- he’s trapped --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the guards and alarm aren’t for him. They're . surrounding a FREAKED-OUT MAN in a white shirt, his voice high, crazed.

dialogues.speaker: FREAKED-OUT MAN
dialogues.text: Is this the return line? Somebody tell me, where’s the return line? The guards tighten the circle. FREAKED-OUT MAN (CONT’D) I’m here to -- I missed a few payments, but -- but I thought rather than make you guys come out -- Raising his scanner, the lead guard PINGS the customer.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: (into radio) We've got an eight month past due pancreas out here. The man unbuttons his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: FREAKED-OUT MAN
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to make it difficult. I know how hard it is, trying to keep a profit margin -- ‘cause you have to pay the -- the Repo Men --

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Sir, just calm down and you can come inside, talk to a credit supervisor. But the guy’s too far gone to talk anything out.

dialogues.speaker: FREAKED-OUT MAN
dialogues.text: So I thought maybe -- maybe if I did it for you -- you’d gimme a break -- He takes off his pants, tossing them on the mall floor, a in the process, he’s pulled out a 9-inch KNIFE -- The guards raise their rifles -- the crowd cowers -- the man raises the knife high -- And STABS it into his own stomach. Everyone stops, transfixed, as he pulls the knife back an forth, committing fully to this odd hari-kari -- Then, raising his free arm high, like a salute -- He PLUNGES his hand into the wound. Grunting softly, his expression barely changing, he tugs at something. Hard. He stumbles forward -- a new scream from the crowd -- and then backwards, still tugging, still searching --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with his final ounce of strength, he yanks mightily - Ripping out his artificial pancreas. He holds it in the air, the cords and tissue and blood dripping to the floor And then collapses in a heap outside the Credit Union doors. Chaos ensues.

dialogues.speaker: CONFUSED GUARDS
dialogues.text: start SHOOTING the dead man’s body -- customers screaming As Frank angrily rushes into the mall. He glances at the carnage and picks up the pancreas.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Who reclaimed this organ? Who reclaimed this goddamned organ???

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: The customer, sir. He did it himself.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Credit Union clients do not reclaim their own organs.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. This one did, sir. Frank stands in the doorway, looking at the bloody mess. Shaking his head. Disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Customers. Don’t know their goddamned place anymore. We MOVE with a pissed-off Frank back into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As all the worried CLIENTS file out of the sales cubicles trying to figure out what the commotion was.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Nothing to worry about, folks. Just a little misunderstanding. Free coffee in the cubicles. Frank pushes past the crowd, moving into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking to his desk -- still steaming -- When the door SLAMS behind him. He turns -- And is suddenly on his knees, forced into a headlock. He looks up --  70.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: stands over him, his bottom half still dressed in the Lar the Lung costume.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Afternoon, boss. With a single move, Remy flings Frank into his office chair. Remy pulls a pistol on him with his left hand -- And with his right, he slaps

dialogues.speaker: A PATCH OF SKIN,
dialogues.text: bearing Ray’s Union tattoo, onto the desk. Still bloody.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s what’1ll happen to the next one you send. And the one after that. I can guarantee you'll run out of Repo Men before I run out of ways to kill them. Frank stares at Remy. At the gun pointed in his face.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Can I say something?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: It’s your office.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: How long before you slip up?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: That's the $800,000 question. Give or take.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And the girl?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You come after her, you come after me. Frank nods -- he understands.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Shoulda taken the job as the lung. You look good in that costume.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Itches like a motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s what the kid says, too. (beat) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t suppose you’1l wanna stick around for an exit interview? Remy smiles a bit at that -- shakes his head -- Then TASERS Frank into unconsciousness. Remy hauls the top half of the Larry the Lung costume bac on. Time to head back out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy, out of costume now but still flush with adrenaline, bounds up the stairs, a bag under his arm --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And into the hotel room. Beth sits at the far end of the room, an odd, strained look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Your knight in bulletproof armor just bought us some more time. Plus, stopped at the store and lifted some of those artichoke hearts you wanted - But Beth’s expression doesn’t change. She looks... scared

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Your ex-wife’s quite the hostess. Served me coffee and everything. Remy freezes. He knows that voice.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: sits behind him, at the other end of the room. The jig is pretty much officially up.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That’s the thing with me and Jake: Somehow, no matter where we were, he always ended up right behind me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DRILL SERGEANT leads a younger Remy, Jake, and a gang o eager soldiers down a long hallway.

dialogues.speaker: DRILL SERGEANT
dialogues.text: You tank boys will be training inside this hangar. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DRILL SERGEANT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is where you will eat, where you will shit, and where you will sleep, because once you’re in the desert, that tank will be your home. You will only be allowed outside into the real world once you have proven that you will not fuck it up. They come to a stop inside a hangar, where tanks sit side by-side, evenly spaced. The drill sergeant hands out numbers. Remy gets number 2; Jake has number 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DRILL SERGEANT (CONT’D) You will be assigned to tanks based on number, because your names no longer matter. In the heat of battle, I do not want your meager minds taxed by the difficulty of remembering your names. He looks down at his clipboard:

dialogues.speaker: DRILL SERGEANT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Number one and number five, take your tank. Don’t touch anything. The two soldiers salute and run toward a tank, scrambling up top to drop down inside. He walks along, assigning mor

dialogues.speaker: TIG
dialogues.text: Numbers four and ten, take your tank. Don’t touch anything. Six and nine, take your tank. Don’t touch anything. Two and eight, take your tank -- Remy and Jake start to run -- BOOM -- an explosion behind them -- SOLDIER #5 is launched upwards out of his tank at 100MPH SLAMMING into the ceiling of the hangar -- And falling, THUDDING to the ground at Remy’s feet, still strapped into an ejection seat. He’s quite dead. A moment later, his parachute opens near the top of the hangar and flutters down next to his body. The sergeant takes one look at the body on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DRILL SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Don't - touch - anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy sits in a control chair -- like the one in the concussion test -- at the front of this high-tech tank, twisting and turning as he tries to get comfy.  73. Jake sits behind him in the gunner’s chair.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Me in front, Jake right behind. That’s how it always worked.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Carol never served me coffee. Jake’s got his taser out, but he’s not pointing it at anyone. Yet. Remy couldn’t make a move if he wanted to. A though their conversation is casual, it’s strained. Tense

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Beth does a lot of things Carol doesn’t do. (beat) I was just at the office. Musta missed you.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Actually, I’m on a new assignment.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Who’s the client?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Just some asshole I spent half my life with. Here’s the thing, though: I got this smokin’ chick coming over tonight.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: And she’s easy --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Just your type.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I'd hate to leave her waiting for me. Maybe it’d be better if I didn’t start hunting this guy down til tomorrow morning. : Remy’s eyes narrow -- is Jake giving him an out?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Sure. Get a good night’s sleep.  74.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Only... the thing that worries me is what happens if this fucker finds a way out of the country before nine A.M. tomorrow? You know I’m a 48 states kinda guy. I don’t do South America.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Then I guess... he’d be clear?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I guess so. If he could get out.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Which he couldn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: No. Never happen. Jake stands, brushes off his pants. Goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Hey -- Jake turns. Remy starts to speak, then stops. Instead of whatever he was going to say, he just says: REMY (CONT’D) See you later.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Try not to. And Jake’s out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long lines snake around the airport terminal as PASSENGER wait to pass through metal and weapons detectors -- As well as walk-through artiforg scanners. A bored-lookin REPO MAN sits next to one of them. He waves a BUSINESSMAN to walk through -- A green wave of light washes over the businessman's body As an ARTIFICIAL LIVER appears inside his body, as if glowing from within. It’s just a projection, a hologram- type image placed onto his frame, but it clearly shows hi artiforg. A PING sounds out, and a bulb above him turns green. He walks through. The Repo Man waves the next passenger in, and we MOVE BAC through the line to find Remy and Beth, waiting their tur Blood from Beth’s knee wound still seeps through a bandag

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: So he’s just letting us go?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Jake doesn’t let anybody go. He’s giving us a head start, that’s all. What we do with it is up to us.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: But nobody ever gets through the airport. I don’t like this.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I’m not in love with it, either. Just try and hide that limp. Remy checks the area, then swiftly walks to the front of the line, lifting his sleeve so the passengers see his tattoo. They don’t come near him. He approaches the bored Repo Man -- who perks up, eyes opening wide -- he recognizes Remy -- Remy grabs him and pulls him to the side, speaking quickl REMY (CONT’D) Look -- I know you know what’s going on, and I know what kind of commission’s in it for you. What I don't know is how many other Union guys you've got in shouting distance, but I’d lay short odds they’11 get here long after my scalpel’s stuck in your throat. (beat) Now: Will you help me?

dialogues.speaker: AIRPORT REPO MAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Christ, man, of course, for you

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Good choice. See the little lady in line? She’s with me. When we go through, all you have to do is shut down the scanner. Once we're past, power it back up again. Two seconds, tops. Got it? The Repo Man nods. Remy’s back to all smiles as he steps line next to Beth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . REMY (CONT’D) It’s taken care of.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: What do I do?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Just walk.  76. Indeed, when they get to the walk-through scanner

dialogues.speaker: THE REPO MAN
dialogues.text: flicks a switch.

dialogues.speaker: REMY AND BETH
dialogues.text: hustle on through and

dialogues.speaker: THE REPO MAN
dialogues.text: flicks the system back on. Just that fast. The lights are back on, more passengers are streaming through, and all seems just like it was before. Remy and Beth walk away, down toward the gates.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: That was easy. Let’s do it again! She playfully turns around, and Remy grabs her waist and spins her back. No time for games yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy and Beth sit on uncomfortable plastic chairs, waitin for their flight to board. The gate sign reads SAO PAOLO, BOARDING 8:35. Remy, tense, checks his watch -- REMY‘S WATCH reads 8:30

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: What do we do once we get there?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: We'll talk about it in the air.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: But --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: In the air. Remy scans the crowd -- passengers going by, everything seems normal -- But something's odd. He stands, looks around -- Out of the corner of his eye, he notices

dialogues.speaker: THREE REPO MEN
dialogues.text: burning down a stairway, heading for their terminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy grabs Beth, running behind the gate counter. The GAT ATTENDANT looks down --

dialogues.speaker: GATE ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Excuse me, this is for airport per -- Remy TASERS the guy, and he falls, hard. He turns to Beth -- and grabs her knee. She winces --

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. This is going to hurt. A lot. Before she can respond, Remy braces her leg with his knee locking her in place -- And whips out a scalpel, going for her knee. We move away As Beth clamps her lips tight, suppressing a scream. Remy working as fast as he can. Just as he said, he’s an exper Seconds later, he holds up her overdue artiforg kneecap.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait here. It’s not as if Beth has a choice -- she’s passed out. Remy pops up from behind the counter and practically jogs up. to the:

dialogues.speaker: AIRPORT REPO MAN
dialogues.text: who looks back and forth -- from Remy to the approaching Repo Men hustling down to the terminal. He’s petrified --

dialogues.speaker: AIRPORT REPO MAN
dialogues.text: C’mon, man, it’s what you would have done --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You're right. With incredible force, Remy JABS an edge of the artificia kneecap between the Repo Man’s shoulder blades. He grunts As Remy steps away, up to the approaching Union Men, and points out the Repo Man, frantically batting at his back. REMY (CONT’D) There he is. Easy commission. The three Union Men, acting on impulse, PING the Airport Repo Man --

dialogues.speaker: THEIR SCANNERS
dialogues.text: all come back the same: DURA-JOINT KNEECAP REPLACEMENT --

dialogues.speaker: AIRPORT REPO MAN
dialogues.text: Wait -- I’m not -- Their tasers fly, and passengers SCREAM. Chaos erupts in the terminal. Remy collects Beth, throws her over his shoulder, and disappears into the frightened crowd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiding behind a dumpster. Remy watches over Beth, who's beginning to wake, slowly. She’s got a tourniquet around her leg, but it’s ugly.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Did we... make it?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Yeah. We made it. Welcome to South America. Beth’s eyes flutter open. She sees the alley. They close again in defeat.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You need a new kneecap.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Great. Let's go down to the Credit Union. Maybe we’1ll get a discount if they kill us both at the same time. Remy lets out a heavy sigh -- there’s no good plan.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know somebody who can help.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: We can’t trust anyone. There’s a reward out --

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Asbury’s clean. He’s outside the Union. Remy stops short -- anger, almost anguish on his face.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Jesus, Beth, you wanna go to an 2? Lemme tell you something about those vermin:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy kneels over an unconscious host. He plucks the liver clean, boxes it, then leaves a yellow receipt on the body He leaves the apartment, shutting the lights off behind him.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Those sleazy motherfuckers took food off my table for years. Black market, aftermarket, whatever you wanna call it, they’re vultures, plain and simple. After several beats of darkness, the door reopens and a flashlight pierces the darkness. A rail thin, beady eyed OUTSIDER sleazoid slinks into the house. Approaches the fallen body, then sets to work, flashlight in mouth, plucking out the remaining artiforgs, tossing them in a sack.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A Union man takes what’s overdue. Outsiders scavenge the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy backs away from Beth. He’s making a stand.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Outsiders are the plague. I’m not going. No fuckin’ way.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: So you’re gonna... what? Knit me a kneecap? Standoff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab pulls to the curb and Remy pulls Beth out, hoisting her over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth, leaning heavily on Remy, knocks on The Outsider’s door. No answer. Remy pounds hard on the door -- nothing. Beth presses against the low ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: He used to leave me a key up here...

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: How well do you know this asshole? Beth just smiles. Remy’s eyes narrow. RUMBLE. Down the hall. It’s a freight elevator. We hear a DING -- the SHOOSH of doors opening -- then a CREAK, CREA Remy tenses, pulling his gun -- edging in front of Beth - A leg slides into view -- only it’s horizontal and three feet off the ground. Then another leg -- And a shopping cart -- with a DEAD BODY inside. Pushing it along is ASBURY, the Outsider. Big ol’ fro, no ring, dark shades -- the Lenny Kravitz look is still hip.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Asbury.

dialogues.speaker: ASBURY
dialogues.text: Little Miss Muffet. Asbury embraces Beth.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Okay, sorority party’s over. Can we get inside? Asbury checks out Remy, scoping him up and down.

dialogues.speaker: ASBURY
dialogues.text: Why'd you drag me a U-man, baby?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: He's a friend. Sort of -- Asbury pulls up Remy’s sleeve -- there’s the Union tattoo Remy knocks his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I’m not with them anymore.

dialogues.speaker: ASBURY
dialogues.text: You quit, or you was quitted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer from Remy; his jaw clenches hard. That’s answer enough for Asbury; he grins and unlocks his door. ASBURY: (CONT’D) Mi casa, viejo.  81. INT. ASBURY’S LOFT - DAY Asbury pushes his cart and dead body inside, Remy and Bet following. Chinese screens are set up throughout the loft separating it into a maze of smaller areas. Asbury rifles through a wall full of cluttered shelves, filled with cardboard boxes and ripped-off artiforgs.

dialogues.speaker: ASBURY
dialogues.text: Thought of you when I tweaked these. He shows Beth a small plastic remote. Off Remy’s stare: ASBURY (CONT’D) Universal remote, U-man. Asbury punches a button on the remote -- Beth’s mouth suddenly opens -- CLICK -- a strange REWIND sound is hear Beth begins talking, clearly not in control of her voice

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: He used to leave me a key up here. Asbury. He’s a friend. Sort of -- Asbury grins and punches another button. Beth shuts up.

dialogues.speaker: ASBURY
dialogues.text: Vocom auto playback, four hour lapse. A real head-blaster at parties. As Asbury pulls the dead body into his work area, Remy takes a look around at all the artiforgs on the shelves.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You pay for these?

dialogues.speaker: ASBURY
dialogues.text: You payin’ for yours?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: That's different --

dialogues.speaker: ASBURY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? I’m Robin Hood, U-man. I can lift a valve out some fresh meat, drop that ‘forg in a client half- cost, cash. Asbury reaches into the stomach wound of the dead body an fishes around with his bare hands. He plucks out a metall liver and tosses it on the table, then goes back for more

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Or he can do it the legal way --

dialogues.speaker: ASBURY
dialogues.text: How’s a vato in the ghetto gonna up- front the Union? Nah, uptown it’s all about the equity. Only equity I care about is hangin’ in your skin.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Ever been out to the desert? The vultures die when the hunters go home.

dialogues.speaker: ASBURY
dialogues.text: So that’s how you wanna play it --

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Boys? Beth lifts her pants leg -- the knee looks even worse tha before. Asbury knocks off the pissing contest.

dialogues.speaker: ASBURY
dialogues.text: Okay. I’m tight with a surgeon gal. She’1l mech up that knee better’n Kenton hisself. Asbury rips out the dead man’s eyeballs and tosses them into a container filled with artiforg eyeballs -- they

dialogues.speaker: SQUISH --
dialogues.text: ASBURY (CONT‘D) Whoops. Natural babies there. He scoops the real eyes out and 3-points them into the trash. INT. SURGEON’S APARTMENT - DAY Beth lays down on a makeshift operating table in this fun run-down apartment.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Asbury says you’re the best mechie around. Reveal ALVA. She has 32 eyebrow rings and purple hair wov into corn rows. Green beads at the end of her braids clic against each other as she moves.

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: Mechie. I swear, I don’t understand what that boy’s saying half the time. Just call me Alva. A seven year old GIRL scampers into the room, her purple hair also woven into corn rows. Same eyebrow jewelry. LIL’ ALVA Another one, mom?

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: Yeah, another one. Just let mama work a minute. Lil’ Alva climbs up and has a seat on the counter right next to Remy, her legs kicking. ALVA (CONT’D) That’s Lil’ Alva. LIL’ ALVA Hey.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Hi. Alva gives Beth an injection in the upper arm.

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: Now, before we start, I need to know about your other artiforgs.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Which ones?

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: All of them.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: To fix my knee?

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: The interrelationships are all real delicate, so I need brand names, dates, everything. Beth takes a deep breath, then launches into it...

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: My intestines are the UltraCoil P Series with optional rapid flush. Liver is a Hexa-Tan, it’s a specialty house in Denmark. I got it in Robin’s Egg Blue, my favorite color. Not that that matters. My kidneys are actually two different models... (eyelids closing) One is Union generic. Didn’t hold up so well. So I upgraded the other... to a top of the line Taihitsu... (yawns) Built-in... ketone monitor... And... boom, Beth’s asleep.

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: Lord, I thought she was gonna go on forever.  84.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Don’t you need to know about her other artiforgs?

dialogues.speaker: ALVA,
dialogues.text: Nah, that’s just my version of count backwards from one hundred. (to Lil’ Alva) Alright, baby. You're up. Lil’ Alva suddenly jumps down off the counter. Approaches Beth’s still body as the elder Alva moves away.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Wait, she’s the surgeon?

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: I just do anesthesia these days. Little one’s got a real steady hand.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: She’s like five years old!

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: She’s seven. But she’s been doing it since she was four. Ain’t that right, pumpkin? LIL’ ALVA Shhh! Lil’ Alva concentrates as she works the laser into Beth’s knee like a kid playing a video game. Remy squirms, but holds his tongue. INT. ASBURY’S LOFT - DAY Asbury hoses down the blood from his work station, hummin himself a tune. A KNOCK at the door interrupts him.

dialogues.speaker: ASBURY
