dialogues.text: (calls out) ‘Lo? My mechie score you up already? No answer. Asbury drops the hose, heads through the Chine screens to investigate. As he arrives in the front hall..

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: swings open to reveal... Jake. ASBURY (CONT’D) U-Man number two. You boys re-gen like the cancer.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I understand you've seen a friend of mine. I need to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asbury’s not sure how to handle this request. As Jake steps into the apartment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy and Beth walk briskly down the sidewalk, keeping the faces hidden. Beth’s knee is better than new, but she doesn’t seem too happy.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you let Raggedy Ann cut on me. And you just stood there --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You're walking fine --

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: That’s not the point. You said it felt weird, so you should’ve stepped in --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I’m not the one who sent you there. Take it up with your Outsider friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth and Remy approach Asbury’s apartment. The front door is open. Remy shoots Beth a look. INT. ASBURY’S LOFT - DAY The loft looks no different, but Remy’s on edge. He steps in front of Beth and leads her through the Chinese screen an intricate maze of blacks and reds -- Asbury is on a sofa, a hole where his stomach used to be. Blood stains the floor, the couch. Beth gasps at the sigh Hand over her mouth, near tears, Beth approaches her dead friend --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Let’s get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: We don’t even know what happened --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: We know enough. Beth kneels by Asbury’s side and closes his eyelids. There’s a WHIRR as his artiforg eyes shut down -- And Beth gets an idea. She runs to a shelf and rifles through a box we saw earlier -- Beth holds up Asbury’s Vocom Universal Remote.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Four-hour lapse, right?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Sure, if he’s got a Vocom -- She points the remote control at Asbury and presses the REWIND button -- Asbury’s jaw CLICKS open, and a WHIRR emanates. Beth hits STOP, looks to Remy. He nods -- go on -- and she pushes PLAY. SCREAMS of pain burst forth from Asbury’s mouth -- Beth, freaked out, STOPS the sound.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Little more rewinding. Beth hits REWIND again, and after a few seconds, she prepares to make another go at it. PLAY. Asbury’s jaw CLICKS open again, and the dead man, with no facial expressions whatsoever, begins to talk, his jaw slightly out of sync with the words:

dialogues.speaker: ASBURY
dialogues.text: -- whoops, natural babies there... You goin’ alone?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: This is it -- keep going --

dialogues.speaker: ASBURY
dialogues.text: Three blocks down, fifth floor. (beat) Go on, I’1l be stylin’ when you flip back around. Sleep it out here if you need to. Hasta luego. (beat; seemingly to self) Damn, girl's looking on top. Beth can’t help but smile at his posthumous compliment. There’s a long pause; Beth hits FAST-FORWARD. As soon as she hears sound -- PLAY -- ASBURY (CONT’D) ‘Lo? My mechie score you up already? (beat) U-man number two. You boys re-gen like the cancer. (beat) Nah, I been alone all day -- I ain’t seen -- hey, watch the skin -- (beat) The fuck offa those -- get the -- (beat) Gonna ping you fierce now motherf --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sudden grunt from Asbury’s throat -- a gurgle -- The SCREAMS start again -- loud, piercing, pained -- Remy punches STOP. He looks to Beth --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They run for the stairs, jumping over some unfinished construction, bricks scattered along the ground. Remy throws open the stairwell door to find --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: He looks almost as upset at seeing Remy as Remy does at seeing him.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Afternoon, partner.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (to Beth) Good to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Can't say the same.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I heard about the airport.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I like to put on a show.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Wish you woulda done a better job of running.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: That makes two of us. Jake leans against a wall, but keeps his eyes on Remy.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Frank’s got everyone’s balls ina vise back at the shop. Security boys working overtime. He couldn’t stand how easy you got inside.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: He thought that was easy?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Any case, he’s doubling commissions on priority one debtors, which is pretty much the two of you. So. thanks.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: My pleasure. Buy a boat. Jake takes a step forward; Remy steps back. A slow circle REMY (CONT’D) Do me one favor.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Anything.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You and me, one on one. Leave her alone. Jake lifts his scanner and PINGS Beth. The screen FILLS with artiforg numbers, all PAST DUE. A Repo Man’s wet dream.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Fine. She walks now.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Wait just a second --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Go. Run downstairs. Don’t look back.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: What am I, a golden retriever?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Take the deal, lady. Beth steps closer to Remy. She’s made her decision. Jake nods -- it’s what he expected. He unholsters his taser.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘1l make it fast. Remy takes out his own taser.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Me, too. Jake sticks his thumb out -- Remy presses his thumb against Jake’s. GRABBING Remy’s wrist, Jake pulls him close, striking out with the taser -- Remy knocking it away, spinning, firing with his own tase The prongs SLAMMING into the wall behind Jake.  89. Remy jumps on top of Jake, wrestling him to the ground. There’s no fancy kung-fu moves -- it’s just a grunt-and- groan contest, each trying to get leverage -- Remy pulling his scalpel from his waistband, getting it u near Jake’s neck, Jake holding him off with one hand -- Reaching for a brick on the ground with the other --

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Look out -- Remy turns to see

dialogues.speaker: THE BRICK
dialogues.text: coming toward his head, Jake whipping it through the air

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Silence. For just a moment, then, fading back in:

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Get up. Come on, get up, we have to get out of here. REMY’S POV - BETH comes into focus, standing over him. They’re still in the Outsider’s hallway --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: lies on the floor, twitching from a taser blast. Beth, taser in her hand, helps Remy to his feet. BETH (CONT’D) You want to finish this off? Remy looks down at the scalpel in his hand, then to Jake. He can’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Let’s just go.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: But --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Now. Back to Alva’s.

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: Ain’t nothing I can do to help you. Alva busies herself, cleaning the surgical equipment. She won't look at either Remy or Beth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lil’ Alva sits atop a table, legs dangling. LIL’ ALVA What about --

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: Hush up. BETH g The guy who’s after us -- he killed Asbury. That doesn’t even matter to you?

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: We all go about our lives in our own ways. Running’s no different. ‘ BETH That’s a nice fucking attitude -- Remy puts a hand out. Stops Beth. Opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: We get it. You’ve got a little girl to protect. I’ve got a son, I understand. Odds are I won't see him again, but... (beat) I definitely understand. They turn to leave. Alva’s clearly upset with herself for turning them away. She takes a moment to make a decision

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: Wait. Remy and Beth stop in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: ALVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: {to Lil’ Alva) Run on up and get momma’s shotgun. Lil’ Alva grins widely and scoots into another room. ALVA (CONT’D) It’s a long way to the railroad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alva leads Remy and Beth down a maze of alleys. Lil’ Alva bounces along next to them, carrying her own shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIL’ ALVA C’mon, slowpokes!

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: Keep your voice down, child.  91.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Are you sure this is the right way? LIL’ ALVA Right up ahead.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Maybe we should turn around -- A chorus of SHOTGUN PUMPS echo out. Remy looks up -- To find himself and Beth surrounded by five MUSCULAR WOME pointing shotguns at them. Lil’ Alva turns and smiles widely. LIL’ ALVA Told ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RHODESIA, a thick black woman with a confident air, leads Remy and Beth through this low-slung hall.

dialogues.speaker: RHODESIA
dialogues.text: Every day, the Union gets hungrier, and every day we take in more just like the two of you. As they walk, Remy’s sleeve rides up. Rhodesia sees his Union tattoo. He self-consciously pulls the sleeve back down.

dialogues.speaker: RHODESIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It don’t matter to me, honey. So long as Alva vouches for you, y’all got a home down here.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Where exactly is “down here?” They’ve come to a door. Rhodesia opens it wide --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Willy Wonka Candy Factory of artificial organs. Row after immense row of twenty-foot shelves are devoted stacking box upon box of high-demand artiforgs. This is where they keep the inventory for wholesale orders.

dialogues.speaker: RHODESIA
dialogues.text: Welcome to the Railroad. Remy runs his hand along a shelf. Artificial hearts, kidneys, livers -- a Union Man’s wet dream.

dialogues.speaker: RHODESIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kenton supply warehouse for the whole city. Can’t nobody ping you up in this hole.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Don’t they check it?

dialogues.speaker: RHODESIA
dialogues.text: “They” is me, and no, I do not. Gal’s got to have a day job, this is mine. Beth looks around at all the artiforgs.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: So if a repo man scans the building --

dialogues.speaker: RHODESIA
dialogues.text: Screen fills with so many ‘forgs makes him wanna cry.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (appreciating the idea) Looking for a haystack in a field of haystacks.

dialogues.speaker: RHODESIA
dialogues.text: Come. on back, we’ll get you set up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A camp, of sorts, inside the warehouse. Ramshackle bunks have been constructed within the artiforg boxes, hasty blankets and mattresses set up on each shelf. Dozens of ragged MEN, WOMEN, AND CHILDREN sit around a sterno pot, warming themselves. A SCRAGGLY MAN, on his last legs, eats food from a tin ca A FAMILY, the FATHER trying to keep his KIDS warm. AN OLD LADY, her artiforg knuckles (gleaming brass, naturally) moving quickly as she knits a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: They’re all wanted by the Union?

dialogues.speaker: RHODESIA
dialogues.text: Most of ‘em. Some are family members, couldn’t stand to let mommy or daddy run on their own. (beat) Now, we'll get you two settled in the far corner. It’ll take a few weeks to find good mattresses, so ‘til then --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Wait, lady -- hold on. We’ve got to get out of the country. Tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smile curls the ends of Rhodesia’s lips. She calls out:

dialogues.speaker: RHODESIA
dialogues.text: Everybody who needs to get out of the country tonight, raise your hand. Everyone’s hand shoots up high. Rhodesia turns back to Remy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’ve got 953 outbounds and six -- count ‘em, six -- jammers on hand. So unless you've got something real damn impressive up your sleeve other than that ugly-ass tattoo, I’d say you’d better find a place to bunk down for the next year or so. Remy looks to Beth. Rhodesia throws them a pair of blankets, and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth does her best to prepare their bunk, piling up blankets, trying to make the shelf, amidst the organs, comfortable. Remy, now without his typewriter, scribbles in longhand o his piece of paper. Beth tries to get a look.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: When do I get to read it?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: When it’s done.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: When's that going to be?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. When I’m dead, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They told me you were here. Had to see it with my own eyes. Remy turns to see T-Bone Bonasera, the record producer whose heart he tried to zap, climb up the edge of the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: T-Bone?

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: In the flesh, baby.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I thought... They told me --

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: I was dead? You think I was gonna stick around, wait for the next Repo Man to pop in? Beth comes over, can’t suppress her grin.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: So that makes two of us that got away from you.

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: (to Beth, re: Remy) This man was my wake-up call. Second I saw him lying on my floor, eyes all glazed, I said T-Bone, you’ve got to get your life in order. So I hightailed it down here to Rhodesia’s, got my ass off the Q, and tonight I’m s’posed to be off to Punta del Este and the warm ocean breeze.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You've got one of the jammers? T-Bone pulls out a small device with a bunch of wires on it.

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: I did. He puts the jammer in Remy’s hands.

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now you do. Remy doesn’t know what to say. He starts to protest, but

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You saved my life. Tried to kill me first, but sometimes that’s how it goes down. Remy’s stunned. He looks to Beth, who looks away. He stands, turning her back around.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You should go. Before me.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: No. The Union wants you more.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You’ve got 15 overdue ‘forgs --

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: But you were one of them. They can’t take the risk of having you on the loose.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: There’s got to be another way -- Beth grabs Remy and kisses him. That shuts him up.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Jake knows you. He knows where you’1l go. And the longer you’re here, the more you put everyone else at risk. It’s the right decision, and Remy knows it.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to leave you.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You’1l find me again. You always do. They stare at one another. There’s no good way to do this

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: Time’s wasting, Repo Man. Remy, with no other choice, takes the jammer and steps to the edge of the shelf. He looks back one last time --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I’1l write you.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: This time, I’1l write back. Remy jumps off the end of the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: INT, EQUIPMENT CENTER
dialogues.text: Remy inspects his spankin’ new passport as Rhodesia hands him his plane ticket.

dialogues.speaker: RHODESIA
dialogues.text: One-way ticket to Bogota. We’ve got people on the other side to get you through the jungle and into Punta del Este.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: And what’s in Punta del Este?

dialogues.speaker: RHODESIA
dialogues.text: It ain’t what’s there -- it’s what’s mot there. No Union. No Repo Men. Just sun and sand and a lotta folks happy to be alive.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Big rock candy mountain. Rhodesia takes Remy’s jammer and wraps it tight around hi waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oeguex.  96.

dialogues.speaker: RHODESIA
dialogues.text: Airports are monitored twenty-four seven by the auto-scanners... Rhodesia pulls out a Repo scanner. She PINGS Remy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHOOPS as the screen fills with Remy’s artiforg heart information. RHODESIA (CONT’D) Now flick it on.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: It won’t work, The Union’s already figured out all the jammer frequencies.

dialogues.speaker: RHODESIA
dialogues.text: Your boys fingered the 3.5 model. This is 3.6. Go on, give it a try. Remy flips a button on the box. There’s no discernible change. Rhodesia PINGS Remy again with the scanner -- Empty. The scanner’s clear, as if Remy’s totally natural.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: How long have these been around?

dialogues.speaker: RHODESIA
dialogues.text: Long enough to fool you, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy, keeping his head down, stands in line at security, waiting to be scanned. Two UNION MEN watch the area. Remy flips the switch on the jammer at his waist -- Then walks through, the green light washing over his body Showing nothing.

dialogues.speaker: UNION MAN
dialogues.text: Move along. Remy walks through. copes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flight to Bogota is boarding. Remy stands there, tick in hand, as other passengers stream by him, onto the flight.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is the final boarding call for flight 862 into Bogota, Columbia.  97. Remy can’t seem to move. He looks at the gateway to the airplane, at his last chance for freedom. The attendant sees him, walks over. ATTENDANT (CONT’D) Sir, are you on flight 862?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I’m supposed to be.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Well, let me just check you in the computer. She takes his ticket and runs it through a scanner. It BEEPS. ATTENDANT (CONT’D) The computer says you're confirmed. Remy’s eyes narrow -- he’s thought of something.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: And the computer would know.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: They always do. So, if you’d care to move onto the jetway, an attendant will show you to your seat. Remy doesn’t move. ATTENDANT (CONT’D) Sir? Are you getting on the flight? We HOLD on Remy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Beth sits on her pile of blankets, leafing through the pages of the book that Remy left behind. She’s all alone.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: How's that book? Beth looks up to see Remy, climbing onto the shelf. She can’t help but smile.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: It’s alright. A little preachy.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: What's it about?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: It’s a fairy tale. Bio-Repo Man loses his heart and finds his soul.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t go that far. (beat) Wanna go to South America?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth and Remy huddle in the subway car, trying to lay low a duffel bag at their feet.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL AND
dialogues.text: have just

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: You already tried hacking the computer.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Not exactly. Before, I was on site, trying to log in bogus ‘forgs.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: So how’s this any different?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: If I can access the mainframe in Union headquarters, I can reprogram the network. Make it think your accounts are all paid in full. You’1l show up clean on the scanners.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Won't they figure it out?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Eventually. But by then we’ll be drinking margaritas and picking sand outta our asses.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Okay, but how are we supposed to get into Union headquarters?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I know a guy on the inside.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh - My - God.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: gotten on the train. Remy tries to move away --

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! Union man! Heads turn. Remy changes tactics.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Sorry, lady. Got the wrong guy.  99.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You could have told me that years ago, saved me the trouble. Remy keeps his voice low, controlled.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: This is not a good time.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Not a good time, you sonofabitch? Other passengers begin to listen in, putting Remy’s surprise melodrama on stage. This could be dangerous. CAROL (CONT’D) That’s a brilliant reason why you took off on your son and haven’t sent a single mortgage payment. Not a good time -- you think that’11l hold up in court? He looks to Peter -- to Carol --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (quietly) I can’t do this right now. Maybe one day I can call and explain, but for now I‘d appreciate it if you’d just go away.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That’s how you handle everything, isn’t it? Rip it out and toss it away. I’m sure that’s exactly what you'd like. All your problems to just disappear, poof, all by themselves -- Suddenly, Carol’s eyes go wide, her entire body tensing with a sudden and powerful jolt. Then she drops to the floor in a heap, eyes rolled back in her head. Remy looks up to see...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: With Remy’s taser in his hand, the metal knobs sparking with residual energy. He smiles, a bit unsure, at Remy -- Who grabs Peter and hugs his boy close.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (happily) That was very naughty what you just did. Very, very naughty. He holds Peter at arm’s length, then reaches into his bag and pulls out the manuscript, bound with a rubber band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMY (CONT’D) When you’re old enough, read this. And if you still want to talk when you‘re done, you come and find me. Peter nods and takes the book as the train pulls into the next station. Remy gives him one more hug -- Remy and Beth hop off the train as the doors close and th train pulls away, taking Peter and a comatose Carol with it.

dialogues.speaker: INT.
dialogues.text: The line of sick, elderly, and frail is endless. Frank begins lowering the steel gate, calling out --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Credit Union number 418 will reopen for business tomorrow morning at ten. A sad groan of disappointment from the masses.

dialogues.speaker: FRAIL LADY
dialogues.text: Sir, please. I may not make it to morning. I’ve been waiting in line since six A.M.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Then show up tomorrow at 5:59.

dialogues.speaker: FRAIL LADY
dialogues.text: I'd like to speak to the manager.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You just did. The gate CLANGS shut and Frank heads off. Reveal Remy and Beth, hiding in the shadows, as they watc Frank walk away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank unlocks his car door, sits inside. A moment of confusion as Frank processes the tiny glass shards all ov the car. Some fucking vandal must have broken his window. Suddenly -- WHAM! Frank’s car seat collapses backward -- As Remy pops up from the backseat and JAMS a long metal trachea into Frank’s open mouth. Blood trickles from Frank's lip as he struggles, chipping a tooth --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Relax, Frank. You might need your air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth on Frank now, wrapping duct tape around his mouth, crudely holding the artiforg windpipe in place. Remy pulls out an artificial lung, clamping it to the trachea. His finger hovers over a tiny black lever. REMY (CONT’D) I flip on this Yoshimoto and dial up deep inhalation mode --

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Suck all the air right outta you.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Instant raisin. Now drive. Remy shoves the seat back up as Frank meekly drops the ca into reverse...

dialogues.speaker: EXT, STREET
dialogues.text: As the car shoots down the road --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gigantic Union sphere and lightning bolt looms on the portico of this state-of-the-art structure. Security cameras sweep the area. Remy and Beth step out from the shadows of the parking lo Remy’s got an unconscious Frank over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (to Beth) Did you have to knock him out?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I don’t trust him.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You don’t have to carry him.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: Frank's face drops into frame, his chin SLAMMING down a metal shelf. Remy pries one of his eyes open. A retinal scan confirms Frank’s identity. A beep, and the door slid open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REMY (CONT’D) See? It’s all who you know. Remy drops Frank's body to the floor and heads inside. Beth follows, and the door closes behind them.  102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A staircase spirals up the darkened lobby. A giant i Computer banks, quite retro in their size, cover the walls. Remy and Beth bolt up the stairs -- §

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single computer sits in the middle of the room, and Rem moves to it. He takes a seat and begins typing. The photos of debtors flick by -- Landing on Remy’s own. A few more keystrokes, and Beth’s face is right beneath his. He hits one more button --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I’ve got it.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: beneath their pictures: PAID IN FULL.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: what -- that easy?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Hey, I’m good.

dialogues.speaker: A METAL LUNG
dialogues.text: comes crashing down on Remy’s head, knocking him to the ground. He looks up -- To see Frank standing over him, raw red skin around his mouth and neck where he’s torn the duct tape off.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: This just makes me sad. You know how hard it is to find a good Repo Man? He kicks Remy in the ribs. Frank’s quite pissed. FRANK (CONT’D) A man who can extract all night long and come in the next morning at nine A.M. ready to do it all again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another kick. Remy tries to stand, gets knocked down -- FRANK (CONT’D) A man who, at the end of the day, just doesn’t give a shit about other people?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They’re a dying breed. Jake stands at the door, taser by his side. He approaches the fallen Remy. Frank, surprised but happy, looks at his watch as he take Remy’s taser from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Let’s wrap this up. I’m a half hour late for my reservation at Le Foie. Jake offers a hand to Remy. Helps him to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I really wish you would have done a better job of running.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: That makes three of us. Suddenly, Beth makes a move, bolting out of the accountin office and escaping into the darkness. REMY (CONT’D) Two of us.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Enough chat, Jake. Jake takes a step toward Remy, who holds his ground.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Sorry about beating your ass in the third grade.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You shoulda seen the other guy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! Do your goddamned job, or I’1l do it for you! Jake nods. Knows what he has to do. Remy nods back.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: A job’s a job. Jake turns to Remy and winks. He flicks his taser on --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Fuck that. And wheels around, SHOOTING the taser at

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: who convulses and drops to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE (CONT’D) You know how long I’ve wanted to do that? Jake gives Remy a hand up. Remy’s eyes go wide --

dialogues.speaker: ON A SECURITY MONITOR
dialogues.text: GUARDS are streaming into the building.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Let’s get the fuck out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake and Remy run for the stairs -- To find two guards already running up. They turn back to the other exit -- To find three more guards coming their way, guns drawn. Jake and Remy go back-to-back. This is it --

dialogues.speaker: A BLOOD-CURDLING SCREAM
dialogues.text: Pierces the silence from behind the guards. Several whip around, but see nobody. Then another piercing voice --

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Please, no, dear God, no -- And another, pleading --

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: -- I have kids, three kids -- Hiding beneath the staircase, we find

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Wielding the Universal Remote from Asbury’s apartment. She’s creating the cacophony, making the repossessed Voco voice boxes housed in the Union play back their dying hosts’ final words. More screams join in, hundreds of pleading voices burstin out at once, all trying to fight off Repo Men for surviva

dialogues.speaker: THE GUARDS
dialogues.text: begin firing in all directions in the confusion. Remy tasers a nearby guard, clearing a path. Jake crunches another’s nose, making a bloody mask.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Over here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy looks to find Beth at the exit. It’s all clear. He runs down the stairs to her, turns -- To see Jake, still on the second floor, fighting off thre more guards.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Come on! A guard sees Remy, runs for him -- And Jake steps in to intercept, tasering the guard -- But leaving himself wide open.

dialogues.speaker: A BULLET
dialogues.text: pierces Jake’s body. Then another. And another. Remy’s powerless to stop it as Jake staggers backwards, tips over the railing and falls towards

dialogues.speaker: THE SPHERE AND LIGHTNING BOLT STATUE BELOW
dialogues.text: The sound is horrific. Jake lies motionless, IMPALED on the giant lightning bolt SPARKS flicker out of the giant computer bank below the bolt as his blood runs into the circuitry. Remy moves’ towards him --

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: We have to go. We have to. Remy stands there, motionless. Beth pulls at his shirt, tugging -- And Remy gives in. They run out. The computer continues to SPARK as Jake’s blood seeps in, sending arcs of electricity through the air.

dialogues.speaker: BETH AND REMY
dialogues.text: run down a long corridor toward the exit, Union computer monitors SPARKING and BLACKING OUT as they run past.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER UNION SECURITY CAMERA
dialogues.text: picks them up as they exit the building --

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SECURITY MONITOR
dialogues.text: as Beth and Remy run for their car -- A burst of STATIC -- and the picture goes to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The long lines, the usual scanners. The same Union Man wh double-crossed Remy earlier on waves the passengers throu First one stops in the scanner, light washes over him:

dialogues.speaker: PAID IN FULL
dialogues.text: Next to step in is

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: moving nervously through the scanner. The wash of light - PAID IN FULL. She smiles, relieved, moves on. And right behind her, moving confidently --

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: walks through the scanner, locking eyes with the Union Ma he knows full well is onto him. But the light comes on: PAID IN FULL. The Repo Man takes out his hand-held scanner and SCANS Re Nothing. No pings, nada. He starts scanning random people PAID IN FULL. PAID IN FULL, PAID IN FULL.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You might wanna get that thing looked at. Remy pats the Repo Man on the back and walks right on by, as the guy angrily pounds his scanner, trying to get it t work. Remy and Beth stroll down the nearest jetway and board th next flight to Bogota. By the time the Repo Man looks up again, they’re gone.

dialogues.speaker: A TV SET, BLACK AND WHITE
dialogues.text: on which an accented reporter gives the news of the day.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: ...which has only added to the worldwide artiforg crisis. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Credit Union spokesmen have denied rumors of sabotage, claiming that they do not yet know what caused the disruption of their computer banks and the sudden closure of all outstanding artiforg accounts, leading to the collapse of the world’s largest corporation.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Nearly every city with a Credit Union Depot has reported widespread looting and vandalism, and many experts believe it’s only a matter of time before martial law is declared across the country... The sounds of the SURF overwhelm the reporter’s voice, an we PULL BACK to find ourselves on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossibly beautiful ocean, beautiful sky. A SUNBATHER turns off his portable TV and returns to his lounging. He got a long, rippled scar in the center of his chest. In fact, everyone on this foreign beach has a scar of som sort or another. The signs all around are in Spanish and Portuguese. As we MOVE through the crowd...

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Christ, it’s hot. Is it supposed to be this hot?

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s the tropics.

dialogues.speaker: REMY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sure, but... Christ, it’s hot. Remy and Beth sit on chaise lounges at the ocean’s edge. Beth’s got on a cute little bathing suit, and though all her scars are showing, she doesn’t seem to care. Remy, still in his somber black-on-black, has a bandage o his shoulder. Beth pulls it down -- the skin is raw and read, but healing. There’s no tattoo. A hardcover book sits on the sand between them.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Are you gonna stay here and act macho or come have some fun? Remy thinks it over.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Macho.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hey, ease up. I don’t want him... uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: Nothing to worry about. If you’d hit him with the brick any lower, it might have posed a problem, but the M- 5 is top of.the line.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What’s he thinking about?

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: No way to know.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: But he’1l be... happy?

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: So long as someone’s paying for the system. Jake nods over to the other side of the hallway -- Where the bottom half of Beth’s torso can be seen. There' more than a bit of blood -- as more ASSISTANTS box up her overdue artiforgs.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I’ve got 15 commissions lying on the floor over there. That should pay it off in full. The other assistants lift Remy’s stretcher up and it pops into place. They begin to roll him down the long hallway. Jake watches him go. JAKE (CONT’D) Sweet dreams, brother. We MOVE WITH Remy, a small smile on his face, those wires trailing out of his brain.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -which is why I’d recommend the M-5 neural net from Kenton. We’re running a special on it this month, just 18 percent interest for the first year, twenty-four after that. Remy, on his cart, moving away from us now, wheeled down that long hall...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Why should your loved one pass on just because of a little brain damage? That's barbaric. That’s just bad science.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: penny:  111.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors at the far end of the hall opening...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: With the new M-5 neural net, the worries of today can be the forgotten woes of yesterday. Imagine your loved ones living the rest of their natural lives in a world where they’re always happy, always content, and always taken care of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The assistants pushing Remy’s cart inside...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You owe it to your family. You owe it to yourself. The elevator doors close. CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, IN HIS OFFICE,
dialogues.text: his smile as wide as ever, staring straight at US.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sign your name right there on the dotted line, and we can get started. He places a pen and contract on the table.
